solutions.content:
After scouring multiple sources, I have managed to condense my solution into the following:

Reference:[ Brilliant solution by @yuanzhi247012 for Leetcode 907](https://leetcode.com/problems/sum-of-subarray-minimums/discuss/284184/Python-Max-Histogram)

```
def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        # Getting list of presums:
        presums = [0] * (len(strength) + 2)
        curr_sum = 0
        
        for i in range(len(strength)):
            curr_sum += strength[i]
            presums[i + 1] = (presums[i] + curr_sum)
            
        strength.append(-1)
        stack = []
        total = 0
        MOD = 1e9 + 7
        
        for i in range(len(strength)):
            while stack and strength[stack[-1]] > strength[i]:
                idx = stack.pop()
                left = stack[-1] if stack else -1
                total += strength[idx] * ((idx - left) * (presums[i] - presums[idx]) - ((i - idx) * (presums[idx] - presums[left])))
            stack.append(i)
            
        return total % (10 ** 9 + 7)
```

__Elaborations:__

_1. Prefix sum:_
Reference: [prefix_sum part of the solution to the problem by @Username1604](https://leetcode.com/problems/sum-of-total-strength-of-wizards/discuss/2534592/Python-O(N)-time-and-space)

I used the following function to calculate the prefix sum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prefix_sum):
```
def get_presums(self, strength):
        n  = len(strength)
        res = [0] * (n + 2)
        cur_sum = 0
        
        for i in range(n):
            cur_sum += strength[i]
            res[i+1] = (res[i] + cur_sum)
                    
        return res
```

_2. Monotonous Increasing Stack:_
Reference: [Beautiful explanantion by @wxd_sjtu for Leetcode 907](https://leetcode.com/problems/sum-of-subarray-minimums/discuss/178876/stack-solution-with-very-detailed-explanation-step-by-step)

Then, I combined the calculation of the __Previous Lesser Element(PLE)__ and the __Next Lesser Element(NLE)__ using __Monotonous Increasing Stack(MIS)__ into one. Individually, the functions would be as follows:

_For PLE_
```
"""
MIS of previous lesser elements. Each element in the PLE stack is the PLE of the element in the input array at the i^th index
"""
def get_ple_stack(arr):
		idx_stack = []
		ple_stack = [-1] * len(arr)
		''' ple_stack[i] = j means arr[j] is PLE of arr[i]
		ple_stack[i] = -1 means arr[i] has no PLE'''
		
		for i in range(len(arr)):
				while idx_stack and arr[idx_stack[-1]] > a[j]:
						idx_stack.pop()
				ple_stack[i] = idx_stack[-1] if idx_stack else -1
				stack.append(i)
				
		return ple_stack
```

_And for NLE_
```
"""
MIS of next lesser elements. Each element in the NLE stack is the NLE of the element in the input array at the i^th index
"""
def get_nle_stack(arr):
		idx_stack = []
		nle_stack = [-1] * len(arr)
		''' nle_stack[i] = j means arr[j] is NLE of arr[i]
		nle_stack[i] = -1 means arr[i] has no NLE'''
		
		for i in range(len(arr)):
				while idx_stack and arr[idx_stack[-1]] > a[j]:
						x = idx_stack.pop()
						nle_stack[x] = i
				idx_stack.append(i)
				
		return nle_stack
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        N = 10**9 + 7
        stack = []                
        r = x = y = 0
        for i, v in enumerate(strength):
            x += v 
            y += (i+1)*v
            while stack and strength[stack[-1][0]] >= v:
                stack.pop()
            pi, pm, pp, px, py = stack[-1] if stack else (-1, 0, 0, 0, 0)
            p = pp + (x - px) * pm + (y - py - (pi + 1) * ((x - px))) * v
            stack.append((i, (pm + (i - pi) * v) % N, p % N, x % N, y % N))
            r = (r + p) % N                    
        return r 
```

```
            p = pp + (x - px) * pm + (y - py - (pi + 1) * ((x - px))) * v
            stack.append((i, (pm + (i - pi) * v) % N, p % N, x % N, y % N))
            r = (r + p) % N                    
        return r
```

solutions.content:
This questions seems exactly the same as https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-subarray-min-product/, but instead of returning the maximim we accumulate the result, but using the same solution and just aggregating the value doesnt work. Why is that?

This is my adapted code from the maximum subarray min-product problem:
```
prefix = [0] * len(strength)
prefix[0] = strength[0]
for i in range(1, len(strength)):
	prefix[i] = prefix[i-1] + strength[i]

strength = strength + [float('-inf')]
prefix = [0] + prefix
stack = []
res = 0
for ind, wizard in enumerate(strength):
	if not stack:
		stack.append(ind)
	else:
		rightB = ind

		while stack and wizard <= strength[stack[-1]]:
			minInd = stack.pop()

			leftB = stack[-1] if stack else -1

			wizSum = prefix[rightB] - prefix[leftB+1]

			res += strength[minInd] * wizSum

		stack.append(ind)

return res
```

solutions.content:
ideas:
(1) use mono-increasing stack to infer the left and right smaller item's index;
(2) for each item, create the prefix sum as well as the prefix multiplication sum;


```
def totalStrength(self, s: List[int]) -> int:
        n=len(s)
        mod=10**9+7
        left=[-1]*n
        right=[n]*n
        st=[]
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            while st and s[st[-1]]>=c:
                right[st[-1]]=i
                st.pop()
            if st:
                left[i]=st[-1]
            st.append(i)
        ##presum: left and right
        ps=[0]*(n+1)
        psr=[0]*(n+1)
        ## pre-multiplication-sum: left and right
        pm=[0]*(n+1)
        pmr=[0]*(n+1)
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            ps[i+1]=(ps[i]+c)%mod
            pm[i+1]=(pm[i]+(i+1)*c)%mod
        for i in range(n-1,-1,-1):
            psr[i]=(psr[i+1]+s[i])%mod
            pmr[i]=(pmr[i+1]+(n-i)*s[i])%mod
        ## loop and sum
        res=0
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            leftsum=(mod+pm[i+1]-pm[left[i]+1]-(1+left[i])*(ps[i+1]-ps[left[i]+1]))%mod
            rightsum=(mod+pmr[i+1]-pmr[right[i]]-(n-right[i])*(psr[i+1]-psr[right[i]]))%mod
            sm=(leftsum*(right[i]-i)+rightsum*(i-left[i]))%mod
            res=(res+sm*c)%mod
        return res
		
## us prefix sum of presum

        n=len(s)
        mod=10**9+7
        left=[-1]*n
        right=[n]*n
        st=[]
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            while st and s[st[-1]]>=c:
               # right[st[-1]]=i
                st.pop()
            if st:
                left[i]=st[-1]
            st.append(i)
        st=[]
        for i in range(n-1,-1,-1):
            while st and s[st[-1]]>s[i]:
                st.pop()
            if st:
                right[i]=st[-1]
            st.append(i)
        
        ##presum: left and right
        ps=[0]*(n+1)
        ps2=[0]*(n+2)
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            ps[i+1]=(ps[i]+c)%mod
        for i in range(n+1):
            ps2[i+1]=(ps2[i]+ps[i])%mod
          
        ## loop and sum
        res=0
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            sm=(mod+ps2[right[i]+1]-ps2[i+1])*(i-left[i])%mod
            sm-=(ps2[i+1]-ps2[left[i]+1])*(right[i]-i)%mod
            res=(res+sm*c)%mod
        return res
```

def totalStrength(self, s: List[int]) -> int:
        n=len(s)
        mod=10**9+7
        left=[-1]*n
        right=[n]*n
        st=[]
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            while st and s[st[-1]]>=c:
               # right[st[-1]]=i
                st.pop()
            if st:
                left[i]=st[-1]
            st.append(i)
        st=[]
        for i in range(n-1,-1,-1):
            while st and s[st[-1]]>s[i]:
                st.pop()
            if st:
                right[i]=st[-1]
            st.append(i)
        
        ##presum: left and right
        ps=[0]*(n+1)
        ps2=[0]*(n+2)
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            ps[i+1]=(ps[i]+c)%mod
        for i in range(n+1):
            ps2[i+1]=(ps2[i]+ps[i])%mod
          
        ## loop and sum
        res=0
        for i,c in enumerate(s):
            sm=(mod+ps2[right[i]+1]-ps2[i+1])*(i-left[i])%mod
            sm-=(ps2[i+1]-ps2[left[i]+1])*(right[i]-i)%mod
            res=(res+sm*c)%mod
        return res

solutions.title: elegant-python-solution-with-o-n
solutions.content:
Let us examine a string `s` with length `n`. We denote its power up until index `i` as `P[i]`.
```
P[0] = s[0]
P[1] = s[0] + s[1] + min(s[0], s[1]) * sum(s[0], s[1])
P[2] = s[0] + s[1] + s[2] + min(s[0], s[1]) * sum(s[0], s[1]) + min(s[1], s[2]) * sum(s[1], s[2]) + min(s[0], s[1], s[2]) * sum(s[0], s[1], s[2])
```
With induction we can prove that:
```
P[k] = P[k-1] + SUM_{i=0}^{k-1} [min(s[i:k]) * sum(s[i:k])]
where P[-1] = 0
```
All we have to do it to add the power of the sub string s[0:n-1] to the sum of the expressions above. The code is very simple: 

```
class Solution(object):
    @staticmethod
    def calcCumPower(substr):
        ret = 0
        n = len(substr)
        for i in range(n):
            ret += min(substr[i:n]) * sum(substr[i:n])
        return ret
    
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        n = len(strength)
        if n == 0:
            return 0
        
        return (self.totalStrength(strength[0:n-1]) + self.calcCumPower(strength)) % (10**9 + 7)
```

```
class Solution(object):

    def calcCumPower(substr):
        ret = 0

        for i in range(n):
            ret += min(substr[i:n]) * sum(substr[i:n])

    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        n = len(strength)
        if n == 0:
            return 0
        
        return (self.totalStrength(strength[0:n-1]) + self.calcCumPower(strength)) % (10**9 + 7)
```

solutions.title: python-o-n
solutions.content:
So excited when coming up with the idea.
But index issue really bothers when it comes to "sum of sum". Sorry for the terrible code style.
```
class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        MOD = int(1e9+7)
        prev_equalsmaller, next_smaller = [-1]*len(strength), [len(strength)]*len(strength)
        stack = []
        for i in range(len(strength)):
            while stack and strength[stack[-1]] > strength[i]:
                x = stack.pop()
                next_smaller[x] = i
            if stack:
                prev_equalsmaller[i] = stack[-1]
            stack.append(i)
            
        subSum = [0]*(len(strength)+1) # subSum[x]:[0:x) -- [i:j) = subSum[j] - subSum[i]
        for i in range(1, len(strength)+1):
            subSum[i] = subSum[i-1] + strength[i-1]
        subSumSum = [0]*(len(subSum)+1) # subSumSum[x]:[0:x) -- [i:j) = subSumSum[j] - subSumSum[i]
        for i in range(1, len(subSum)+1):
            subSumSum[i] = (subSumSum[i-1] + subSum[i-1]) % MOD
        
        ans = 0
        for x in range(len(strength)):
            i, j = prev_equalsmaller[x], next_smaller[x]
            m, n = x - i, j - x 
            # (i,x] --> -[i,x) subSum[i+1]~subSum[x] subSumSum[x+1] - subSumSum[i+1]
            # [x, j) --> subSum[x+1] ~ subSum[j] subSumSum[j+1] - subSumSum[x+1]
            total = (subSumSum[j+1] - subSumSum[x+1]) * (x - i) - (subSumSum[x+1] - subSumSum[i+1]) * (j - x)
            total = (total % MOD)*strength[x] % MOD
            ans = (ans + total) % MOD
        return ans
```

```
class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        MOD = int(1e9+7)
        prev_equalsmaller, next_smaller = [-1]*len(strength), [len(strength)]*len(strength)
        stack = []
        for i in range(len(strength)):
            while stack and strength[stack[-1]] > strength[i]:
                x = stack.pop()
                next_smaller[x] = i
            if stack:
                prev_equalsmaller[i] = stack[-1]
            stack.append(i)
            
        subSum = [0]*(len(strength)+1) # subSum[x]:[0:x) -- [i:j) = subSum[j] - subSum[i]
        for i in range(1, len(strength)+1):
            subSum[i] = subSum[i-1] + strength[i-1]
        subSumSum = [0]*(len(subSum)+1) # subSumSum[x]:[0:x) -- [i:j) = subSumSum[j] - subSumSum[i]
        for i in range(1, len(subSum)+1):
            subSumSum[i] = (subSumSum[i-1] + subSum[i-1]) % MOD
        
        ans = 0
        for x in range(len(strength)):
            i, j = prev_equalsmaller[x], next_smaller[x]
            m, n = x - i, j - x 
            # (i,x] --> -[i,x) subSum[i+1]~subSum[x] subSumSum[x+1] - subSumSum[i+1]
            # [x, j) --> subSum[x+1] ~ subSum[j] subSumSum[j+1] - subSumSum[x+1]
            total = (subSumSum[j+1] - subSumSum[x+1]) * (x - i) - (subSumSum[x+1] - subSumSum[i+1]) * (j - x)
            total = (total % MOD)*strength[x] % MOD
            ans = (ans + total) % MOD
        return ans
```

solutions.title: racket-solution-and-explanation
solutions.content:
Explanation

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/b0798aed-c2fe-40fb-a17d-a567ade23137_1653589261.7779553.png)
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/67bbe428-498c-40d1-9804-8f52a0e4b5c1_1653589280.2554514.png)
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/ee6adc7d-bad8-49cb-92da-7dfc9b7074d6_1653589291.030931.png)

Racket code

```scheme
(define/contract (total-strength strength)
  (-> (listof exact-integer?) exact-integer?)

  (define len (length strength))

  (define prev-smaller-lst
    (let ([stk '()]
          [get-strength (lst-ith strength #f)])
      (for/list ([i len]
                 [v strength])
        (let ([remain (dropf stk (lambda (j) (>= (get-strength j) v)))])
          (set! stk (cons i remain))
          (if (null? remain)
              -1
              (car remain))))))

  (let* ([psum (get-prefixsum strength)]
         [fpsum (lst-ith psum 0)]
         [ppsum (get-prefixsum psum)]
         [fppsum (lst-ith ppsum 0)]
         [eq1s (make-vector len)]
         [eq2s (make-vector len)]
         [results
          (for/list ([i len]
                     [v strength]
                     [k prev-smaller-lst])
            (let ([eq1 (mod (+ (if (= k -1) 0 (vector-ref eq1s k))
                               (mod (* (- i k) v))))]
                  [eq2 (mod (+ (if (= k -1) 0 (vector-ref eq2s k))
                               (mod (* v (- (fppsum (- i 1))
                                            (fppsum (- k 1)))))))])
              (vector-set! eq1s i eq1)
              (vector-set! eq2s i eq2)
              (mod (- (mod (* (fpsum i) eq1)) eq2))))])
    (foldl (compose mod +) 0 results)))

(define (mod x) (modulo x (+ #e1e9 7)))

;; helpers ;;

(define (lst-ith lst default)
  (let ([vec (list->vector lst)])
    (lambda (i)
      (if (< i 0)
          default
          (vector-ref vec i)))))

(define (get-prefixsum lst)
  (scanl (compose mod +) 0 lst))

(define (scanl f init lst)
  (let ([acc init])
    (for/list ([v lst])
      (set! acc (f v acc))
      acc)))
```

solutions.title: what-am-i-doin-wrong
stacks-and-prefix-sums-with-python
solutions.content:
Hello! Admittedly, my solution is not very efficient (max was >54%), but it is one that I understand what I'm typing, so I hope it is helpful. And it was approved, so I won't complain too much.

Anyhow, do scroll down all the way for the python code, below is the explanation first

My first solution was to have a layer of [min, sum] for each element, and then add them rightwards. The layers would get increasingly smaller until it is of length 1. So the time complexity of n!, which isn't fast enough. But this n! algorithm, and the other solutions posted here on discussion, helped me realise that many of the sums can share a common minimum element.

This leads to the next idea: from which index to which index is the element at my current index the minimum of every subarray (including the *current element*)? First, we initialise two arrays, onTheLeft and onTheRight, to track how many indices, on the left and on the right respectively, reference an element larger than my current element (i.e. which my current element is the minimum). Their initial values will be their own index.

Our target at the end is to get the following information for every index: start, anchor, end.
* anchor: the current index
* start: The starting index of the subarray in which my anchor is the minimum
* end: The final index (inclusive) of the subarray in which my anchor is the minimum
To get the indices we want, when we iterate through the strengths, we will make use of a stack. Let's say we are searching for the start indices of each index (i.e. using the onTheLeft list). When we use the stack, we will:
1. first check that it is not empty
2. Let the current index be x. take a look at the index of the top stack, let's call this index y. if the strength of  index y is larger than the strength of index x, I will set the starting index of x to the *start index of the index y*. Think about it like this: If the strength at index x is smaller than the strength at index y, remember that the strength of index y is the smallest of it's own subarray. Therefore the strength of index x is also smaller than the strength at the starting index of index y.
3. remove index y
4. append index x
note that index y's starting index is not lost. it is captured as index x's starting index!

for the case of the ending index, using the onTheRight, it is essentially the reverse of onTheLeft, so using negative indexing.

before computing the contiguous sums, we will need some helpful prefix sums to make life slightly easier. the first prefix sum is just the sum of strengths until the index you are at (i.e. if you use sum(strength[:idx])) you would get the same as prefix[idx]). The second prefix sum list is the sum of those prefix sums. Using the test case example [1, 3, 1, 2]:
prefix = [1, 1+3, 1+3+1, 1+3+1+2]
prefixPrefix = [(1), (1) + (1+3), (1) + (1+3) + (1+3+1), (1) + (1+3) + (1+3+1) + (1+3+1+2)] 
we append 0s to the end of each arrays in the event where we get a -1 index, we don't want it to affect our calculations

Next up is to get the contiguous sums of every subarray of each index. To know what contiguous sums to compute, we will need to generalise how we use the start, anchor and end indices. Let's consider two portions in every contiguous sum, the start-to-anchor (startAnchor) and anchor-to-end (anchorEnd) portions. i will talk about what each expression is doing:

anchorEnd
- **prefixPrefix[end] - prefixPrefix[anchor - 1]**: This leaves behind the sum of sums of subarrays from the start (of the strength list) to each index from the anchor to end, inclusive. (i.e. sum( strength[anchor:end+1] + strength[anchor+1:end] + ... + strength[anchor] )
-  **- prefix[anchor - 1] * (end - anchor + 1)**: This removes the sum of elements from the start (of the strength list) to just before the anchor (i.e. sum(strength[:anchor-1])). For each of the subarrays, we will need to remove this sum(strength[:anchor-1]), which is obtained from (end - anchor + 1)
-  **times (anchor - start + 1)**: From our last two steps, we have obtained the contiguous sum of subarrays from strength[anchor:end+1]. We will need to take this sum and multiply it by the number of indices from start to anchor, + 1. Each of these contiguous sums can be seen as attached to each contiguous array from strength[start:anchor]. The +1 is for the contiguous sum that is not attached to any subarray.

startAnchor
- First, an observation. If we were to write out the elements of subarrays involved in calculating anchorEnd, with the longest one on top to the shortest one below (which would just be the anchor itself), we would notice a slant of elements (like y = x line). But if we were to do this for the subarrays in startAnchor, it would be in a different direction (like a y = -x line). Remember that the anchor is the lowest value in the subarrays, so we are decreasing the index from the left to the right (i.e. if our start to anchor is [4,3,2,1], with 4 being the start and 1 being the anchor, our subarrays are [4,3,2], [3,2], [2] (also note that 1 is calculated in anchorEnd, so do not double count here). )
- **(prefix[anchor - 1] - prefix[start - 1]) * (anchor - start + 1)**: This gives us the sum of the subarray strength[start: anchor], times the number of indices between start and anchor. Think about it like a rectangle, and we are going to chop off a triangle at the bottom left
- **(prefixPrefix[anchor - 1] - prefixPrefix[start - 1] - prefix[start - 1] * (anchor - start))**: This is almost the same steps as in anchorEnd, but the triangle obtained (if you were to draw out the elements) is one index shorter. This is because this sum is the sum we are going to use as the triangle to chop off our rectangle
- **times (end - anchor + 1)**: lastly, we repeat this sum for the number of indices between the end and anchor, same reasoning as for anchorEnd

and so we have everything we neeed, just one last loop through the strengths, retrieve your values for start, anchor and end, plug those values for the contiguous sum and add it to your result.


**Python**
```
class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        MOD = 10 ** 9 + 7    
        res = 0
        
        stackLeft, stackRight = [], []
        onTheLeft = [i for i in range(len(strength))]
        onTheRight = [j for j in range(-len(strength), 0)]
        prefix, prefixPrefix = [strength[0]], [strength[0]]
        for i in range(len(strength)):
            while stackLeft and strength[i] < strength[stackLeft[-1]]:
                onTheLeft[i] = onTheLeft[stackLeft[-1]]
                stackLeft.pop()
            stackLeft.append(i)
            
            while stackRight and strength[-i-1] <= strength[stackRight[-1]]:
                onTheRight[-i-1] = onTheRight[stackRight[-1]]
                stackRight.pop()
            stackRight.append(-i-1)
            
            if i == 0:
                continue
            prefix.append(prefix[-1] + strength[i])
            prefixPrefix.append(prefix[-1] + prefixPrefix[-1])
        
        prefix += [0]
        prefixPrefix += [0]
        
        for k in range(len(strength)):
            start, end = onTheLeft[k], onTheRight[k] + len(strength)
            sums = self.contiguousSums(prefix, prefixPrefix, start, k, end)
            res += (sums * strength[k]) % MOD
        return res % MOD

    def contiguousSums(self, prefix, prefixPrefix, start, anchor, end):
        anchorEnd = (prefixPrefix[end] - prefixPrefix[anchor-1] - prefix[anchor - 1] * (end - anchor + 1)) * (anchor - start + 1)
        startAnchor = ((prefix[anchor - 1] - prefix[start - 1]) * (anchor - start + 1) - (prefixPrefix[anchor - 1] - prefixPrefix[start - 1] - prefix[start - 1] * (anchor - start))) * (end - anchor + 1)
        return (anchorEnd + startAnchor)
```

will I remember how to do this? probably not.

```
                stackRight.pop()

        return res % MOD
```

solutions.title: python-o-n-dp-using-spans-and-cumulative-sums
solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
  def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
    n = len(strength)
    spans = [[-1, n] for _ in range(n)]
    stack = deque()
    for i in range(n):
      while len(stack) > 0 and strength[i] < strength[stack[-1]]:
        spans[stack[-1]][1] = i
        stack.pop()
      if len(stack) > 0:  
        spans[i][0] = stack[-1]
      stack.append(i)
      
    s = 0
    cumSum = [0 for _ in range(n)]
    for i in range(n):
      s += strength[i]
      cumSum[i] = s
      
    s = 0
    cumCumSum = [0 for _ in range(n)]
    for i in range(n):
      s += cumSum[i]
      cumCumSum[i] = s
      
    s = 0
    reverseCumSum = [0 for _ in range(n)]
    for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
      s += strength[i]
      reverseCumSum[i] = s
      
    s = 0
    reverseCumCumSum = [0 for _ in range(n)]
    for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
      s += reverseCumSum[i]
      reverseCumCumSum[i] = s
      
    tot = 0
    m = 1000000007
    for i in range(n):
      st = strength[i]
      sp = spans[i]
      l = i - sp[0] - 1
      r = sp[1] - i - 1
      s = 0
      s += (l + 1) * ((r * st) + cumCumSum[sp[1] - 1] - cumCumSum[i] - (r * cumSum[i]))
      s += (r + 1) * ((l * st) + reverseCumCumSum[sp[0] + 1] - reverseCumCumSum[i] - (l * reverseCumSum[i]))
      s -= ((l * r) - 1) * st
      tot += (st * s)
      tot %= m
      
    return tot
        
```

```
    reverseCumCumSum = [0 for _ in range(n)]
    for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
      s += reverseCumSum[i]
      reverseCumCumSum[i] = s
      
    tot = 0
    m = 1000000007
    for i in range(n):
      st = strength[i]
      sp = spans[i]
      l = i - sp[0] - 1
      r = sp[1] - i - 1
      s = 0
      s += (l + 1) * ((r * st) + cumCumSum[sp[1] - 1] - cumCumSum[i] - (r * cumSum[i]))
      s += (r + 1) * ((l * st) + reverseCumCumSum[sp[0] + 1] - reverseCumCumSum[i] - (l * reverseCumSum[i]))
      s -= ((l * r) - 1) * st
      tot += (st * s)
      tot %= m
```

solutions.title: python-o-nlogn-presum-of-presum-and-binary-search-easy-understand
solutions.content:
For strength array [*a0,a1, ..., a(n-1)*],  we mark its presum as [*0, p0, p1, ..p(n-1)*], let *ai* is the minimal value in the range[*al,ar*], where *l <= i <= r*, so contribution of *ai* to answer is:
*ai * (pi - p(l-1)) + (pi - pl) +...+(pi-p(i-1)) + (p(i + 1) -p(l-1)) + (p(i + 1) - pl) +...+(p(i+ 1)-p(i-1)) +...+ (p(i + 1)-p(i-1)) + ... + (p(r + 1) - p(l-1)) + ( p(r + 1) - pl) +...+( p(r + 1)-p(i-1)) = (r - l + 1)  (pi + p(i + 1) +...+p(r + 1) - (i - left + 1) * (pl + p(l + 1) + ...p(i - 1))*. 
We can find its another accumate sum, we mark presum of [*0, p0, p1, ..pn-1*] as [*0, 0, acc0,acc1, ..., acc(n-1)*], so last equation tunrns to:
*ai  * ((r - i + 1)  (acc(r + 1) - acc(i)) - (i - left + 1)  * (acc[i] - acc[left - 1]))*
After this, we need to get the range[*al,ar*],  one way is to use monotonic stack; here we deal with it from least value to most value so we can use bianry search and insert to find left and right bound, in the code we use *idxs* to store value index used in order.
```
from bisect import bisect

class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        n = len(strength) + 1
        idxs, ans, MOD = [], 0, 10 ** 9 + 7
        presum, accsum = [0] * n, [0] * (n + 1)
        for i in range(n - 1):
            presum[i + 1] = (presum[i] + strength[i])
            accsum[i + 2] = (accsum[i + 1] + presum[i + 1]) % MOD
        for v, p in sorted((v, p + 1) for p, v in enumerate(strength)):
            pos = bisect(idxs, p)
            left = 0 if not idxs or pos == 0 else idxs[pos - 1]
            right = n if not idxs or pos == len(idxs) else idxs[pos]
            ans = (ans + v * ((p - left) * (accsum[right] - accsum[p]) - (right - p) * (accsum[p] - accsum[left]))) % MOD
            idxs[pos:pos] = [p]
        return ans
```

```
class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
```
```
        KMAX = 10 ** 9 + 7
        res, N = 0, len(strength)
        presum, total, tt, pl2r = [], 0, 0, []
        for i, v in enumerate(strength):
            total += v
            presum.append(total)
            tt += total
            pl2r.append(tt)
        
        pr2l, total, tt = [], 0, 0
        for i in range(N - 1, -1, -1):
            total += strength[i]
            tt += total
            pr2l.append(tt)
        pr2l.reverse()
            
        def complexsum(l, m, r):
			# use triangle to find the subarray sum between l and r (inclusive).
            res = (m - l + 1) * (r - m + 1) * strength[m]
            res += (m - l + 1) * ((total - presum[m]) * (r - m) - (pr2l[m + 2] if m < N - 2 else 0) + (pr2l[r+2] if r < N - 2 else 0))
            res += (r - m + 1) * ((presum[m-1] if m > 0 else 0) * (m - l) - (pl2r[m-2] if m > 1 else 0) + (pl2r[l-2] if l > 1 else 0))
            return res % KMAX
    
		# this is the same as in 907.
        stk = []
        for i in range(N):
            while stk and strength[stk[-1]] > strength[i]:
                idx = stk.pop()
                res += strength[idx] * complexsum((stk[-1] + 1) if stk else 0, idx, i - 1)
                res %= KMAX
            stk.append(i)
        while stk:
            idx = stk.pop()
            res += strength[idx] * complexsum((stk[-1] + 1) if stk else 0, idx, N - 1)
            res %= KMAX
        return res
```

solutions.content:
Key steps:

1. Iterate through the strength list and take every strength value as the current weakest one, then find all the substrings taking this current value as its weakest strength. If there are multiple weakest strength in a substring, we always take the left-most one. With this rule, we can find the left and right index bound of such substrings.
2. Calculate the sum of substrings within the left and right bounds and ending at / starting from the current strength (but not inclusive) respectively, named as as **sum_l** and **sum_r**. Accelerate the calculation by a trick of computing the "**sum of sums**" in advance, please read the code on the bottom for the detail(calculating sum2_list).
3. Assume **i**, **s** are the current index and strength while lb, rb are the index of current left / right bound (left close right open), **nl**, **nr** = i - lb, rb - 1 - i are the number of strength values within the bounds and on the left / right of the current strength s at index i.
4. Finally we have **inc** = (sum_l * (nr + 1) + sum_r * (nl + 1) + s * (nl + 1) * (nr + 1)) * s, where inc is the total strength of all substrings taking the current strength as the weakest one.
5. Sum the inc value of all elements in the strength list and mod it by 10 ** 9 + 7, then we get the answer.

The overall time complexity is **O(N)**.

Here is the code:
```
class Solution:
    def totalStrength(self, strength: List[int]) -> int:
        MOD = 10 ** 9 + 7
        N = len(strength)
        bounds = [[0, N] for _ in range(N)]
        
        # cal bounds
        # (ind, strength)
        stack = []
        for i, s in enumerate(strength):
            while stack and stack[-1][1] > s:
                bounds[stack[-1][0]][1] = i
                stack.pop()
            stack.append((i, s))
        
        while stack:
            bounds[stack[-1][0]][1] = N
            stack.pop()
            
        for i in range(N-1, -1, -1):
            s = strength[i]
            while stack and stack[-1][1] >= s:
                bounds[stack[-1][0]][0] = i + 1
                stack.pop()
            stack.append((i, s))
        
        while stack:
            bounds[stack[-1][0]][0] = 0
            stack.pop()
        
        # cal sum_list
        sum_list = [0]
        for s in strength:
            sum_list.append(sum_list[-1] + s)
            
        sum2_list = [0]
        for s in sum_list:
            sum2_list.append(sum2_list[-1] + s)
        
        # cal ans
        ans = 0
        for i, s in enumerate(strength):
            lb, rb = bounds[i]
            assert lb <= i < rb
            nl, nr = i - lb, rb - 1 - i
            
            sum_l = sum_list[i] * nl - (sum2_list[i] - sum2_list[i-nl])
			# sum_l = 0
            # for j in range(i-nl, i):
            #    sum_l += sum_list[i] - sum_list[j]
            
            sum_r = (sum2_list[i+nr+2] - sum2_list[i+2]) - sum_list[i+1] * nr
			# sum_r = 0
            # for j in range(i+2, i+nr+2):
            #     sum_r += sum_list[j] - sum_list[i+1]
            
            inc = (sum_l * (nr + 1) + sum_r * (nl + 1) + s * (nl + 1) * (nr + 1)) * s
            inc %= MOD
            
            ans = (ans + inc) % MOD
        return ans
        
        
```

```
            while stack and stack[-1][1] > s:
                bounds[stack[-1][0]][1] = i
                stack.pop()
            stack.append((i, s))
        
        while stack:
            bounds[stack[-1][0]][1] = N
            stack.pop()
            
        for i in range(N-1, -1, -1):
            s = strength[i]
            while stack and stack[-1][1] >= s:
                bounds[stack[-1][0]][0] = i + 1
                stack.pop()
            stack.append((i, s))
        
        while stack:
            bounds[stack[-1][0]][0] = 0
            stack.pop()
        
        # cal sum_list
        sum_list = [0]
        for s in strength:
            sum_list.append(sum_list[-1] + s)
            
        sum2_list = [0]
        for s in sum_list:
            sum2_list.append(sum2_list[-1] + s)
        
        # cal ans
        ans = 0
        for i, s in enumerate(strength):
            lb, rb = bounds[i]
            assert lb <= i < rb
            nl, nr = i - lb, rb - 1 - i
            
            sum_l = sum_list[i] * nl - (sum2_list[i] - sum2_list[i-nl])
			# sum_l = 0
            # for j in range(i-nl, i):
            #    sum_l += sum_list[i] - sum_list[j]
            
            sum_r = (sum2_list[i+nr+2] - sum2_list[i+2]) - sum_list[i+1] * nr
			# sum_r = 0
            # for j in range(i+2, i+nr+2):
            #     sum_r += sum_list[j] - sum_list[i+1]
            
            inc = (sum_l * (nr + 1) + sum_r * (nl + 1) + s * (nl + 1) * (nr + 1)) * s
            inc %= MOD
            
            ans = (ans + inc) % MOD
        return ans
```

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/94ac9010-57fc-44e5-93b3-e3ceda88a3cb_1653193278.7448575.jpeg)

1. https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/1729637/amazon-new-grad-role-2022/
2. https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/1736639/Solution-to-Amazon-OA-2022-problem-Sum-of-Scores-of-Subarray

[Original Post](https://leetcode.com/problems/sum-of-total-strength-of-wizards/discuss/2061985/Python-Solution-O(n))

The monotonic stack is self-explanatory. Just explaining "(racc * ln - lacc * rn)" in greater detail:

Say our input is [5,3,1,2]

Using monotonic stack, Left is [-1, -1, -1, 2], Right is [1, 2, 4, 4].

Now look at the 1 (at input array, index 2), it is the minimum for the [1], [3, 1], [5, 3, 1], [1, 2], [3, 1, 2], [5, 3, 1, 2]. So its “contribution” to the final result will be as follows:
1 * (sum([1]) + sum([3,1]) + sum([5,3,1]) + sum([1,2]) + sum([3,1,2]) + sum([5,3,1,2]))

So how do we find this “sum of sums”, given that we know the left most element that < 1 is at index -1 (means non-existent), and the rightmost element that is ≤ 1 is at index 4 (means non-existent)?

Lee’s Solution: prefix of prefix sums, which is the “acc” variable in his code.
For our example, “acc” is [0, 5, 13, 22, 33]. Let’s see which each element really means:
5 = (5)
13 = (5) + (5+3)
22 = (5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1)
33 = (5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)

So how do we tie these parts together?
Note that in our example, there is a 2 larger numbers to 1’s left, and 1 larger number to 1’s right. This can be generalized into a pattern: if there are x larger numbers to the left to 1, and y larger numbers to its right: when we fix x, there can be y + 1 combinations on the right, or when we fix y, there can be x + 1 combinations on the left.

Key: The way I understand it is that we are trying to build a “template” first, then cancel out some of numbers.

First we do 33 – 13. Why? Look at the underlying.
33 – 13 = [(5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)] – [(5) + (5+3)] = [(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
We are looking at 1 right now, so we don’t want to consider any subarray that doesn’t contain 1. Note this 20 is sum of 2 subarray sums.

Next, we use 20 * 3. Why? Because we are trying to create a “template” here. Notice how because of the generalized pattern above, we will have 6 combinations (we can fix x to be 0 / 1 / 2, and y can be 0 / 1. For example, when x=0 and y=0, our combination is [1], or when x=2, y=0, our combination is [5,3,1]). Since 20 is sum of 2 subarray sums, and we want 6 combinations, we duplicate 20 3 times. So we now have:
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]

Next, we do 13 – 0. Look at the underlying.
13 – 0 = (5) + (5+3)

Then 13 * 2. Now you might think why 2 not 3 (because 13 is sum of 2 subarrays), right? Proceed and I will explain it later:

Finally, 20 * 3 - 13 * 2. Visually, this can be understood as follows:
[(<s>**5+3**</s>+1) + (<s>**5+3**</s>+1+2)]
[(<s>**5**</s>+3+1) + (<s>**5**</s>+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)].
Note that while the same cancellation strategy is applied horizontally, each 13 is the group of subarrays used for cancellation vertically. So how many 13 will we use? Depends on how many columns we have, which in turn 1 + number of bigger numbers to its right.

Then you might ask, if we do “racc * ln - lacc * rn”, does that mean “ln” always has to be ≥ “rn”? No, repeat the above for [5,1,3,2], and we can get the following cancellation outcome.
[(<s>**5**</s>+1) + (<s>**5**</s>+1+3) + (<s>**5**</s>+1+3+2)]
[(5+1) + (5+1+3) + (5+1+3+2)]

2. https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/1736639/Solution-to-Amazon-OA-2022-problem-Sum-of-Scores-of-Subarray

[Original Post](https://leetcode.com/problems/sum-of-total-strength-of-wizards/discuss/2061985/Python-Solution-O(n))

The monotonic stack is self-explanatory. Just explaining "(racc * ln - lacc * rn)" in greater detail:

Say our input is [5,3,1,2]

Using monotonic stack, Left is [-1, -1, -1, 2], Right is [1, 2, 4, 4].

Now look at the 1 (at input array, index 2), it is the minimum for the [1], [3, 1], [5, 3, 1], [1, 2], [3, 1, 2], [5, 3, 1, 2]. So its “contribution” to the final result will be as follows:
1 * (sum([1]) + sum([3,1]) + sum([5,3,1]) + sum([1,2]) + sum([3,1,2]) + sum([5,3,1,2]))

So how do we find this “sum of sums”, given that we know the left most element that < 1 is at index -1 (means non-existent), and the rightmost element that is ≤ 1 is at index 4 (means non-existent)?

Lee’s Solution: prefix of prefix sums, which is the “acc” variable in his code.
For our example, “acc” is [0, 5, 13, 22, 33]. Let’s see which each element really means:
5 = (5)
13 = (5) + (5+3)
22 = (5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1)
33 = (5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)

So how do we tie these parts together?
Note that in our example, there is a 2 larger numbers to 1’s left, and 1 larger number to 1’s right. This can be generalized into a pattern: if there are x larger numbers to the left to 1, and y larger numbers to its right: when we fix x, there can be y + 1 combinations on the right, or when we fix y, there can be x + 1 combinations on the left.

Key: The way I understand it is that we are trying to build a “template” first, then cancel out some of numbers.

First we do 33 – 13. Why? Look at the underlying.
33 – 13 = [(5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)] – [(5) + (5+3)] = [(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
We are looking at 1 right now, so we don’t want to consider any subarray that doesn’t contain 1. Note this 20 is sum of 2 subarray sums.

Next, we use 20 * 3. Why? Because we are trying to create a “template” here. Notice how because of the generalized pattern above, we will have 6 combinations (we can fix x to be 0 / 1 / 2, and y can be 0 / 1. For example, when x=0 and y=0, our combination is [1], or when x=2, y=0, our combination is [5,3,1]). Since 20 is sum of 2 subarray sums, and we want 6 combinations, we duplicate 20 3 times. So we now have:
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]

Next, we do 13 – 0. Look at the underlying.
13 – 0 = (5) + (5+3)

Then 13 * 2. Now you might think why 2 not 3 (because 13 is sum of 2 subarrays), right? Proceed and I will explain it later:

Finally, 20 * 3 - 13 * 2. Visually, this can be understood as follows:
[(<s>**5+3**</s>+1) + (<s>**5+3**</s>+1+2)]
[(<s>**5**</s>+3+1) + (<s>**5**</s>+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)].
Note that while the same cancellation strategy is applied horizontally, each 13 is the group of subarrays used for cancellation vertically. So how many 13 will we use? Depends on how many columns we have, which in turn 1 + number of bigger numbers to its right.

Then you might ask, if we do “racc * ln - lacc * rn”, does that mean “ln” always has to be ≥ “rn”? No, repeat the above for [5,1,3,2], and we can get the following cancellation outcome.
[(<s>**5**</s>+1) + (<s>**5**</s>+1+3) + (<s>**5**</s>+1+3+2)]
[(5+1) + (5+1+3) + (5+1+3+2)]

Note that in our example, there is a 2 larger numbers to 1’s left, and 1 larger number to 1’s right. This can be generalized into a pattern: if there are x larger numbers to the left to 1, and y larger numbers to its right: when we fix x, there can be y + 1 combinations on the right, or when we fix y, there can be x + 1 combinations on the left.

Key: The way I understand it is that we are trying to build a “template” first, then cancel out some of numbers.

First we do 33 – 13. Why? Look at the underlying.
33 – 13 = [(5) + (5+3) + (5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)] – [(5) + (5+3)] = [(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
We are looking at 1 right now, so we don’t want to consider any subarray that doesn’t contain 1. Note this 20 is sum of 2 subarray sums.

Next, we use 20 * 3. Why? Because we are trying to create a “template” here. Notice how because of the generalized pattern above, we will have 6 combinations (we can fix x to be 0 / 1 / 2, and y can be 0 / 1. For example, when x=0 and y=0, our combination is [1], or when x=2, y=0, our combination is [5,3,1]). Since 20 is sum of 2 subarray sums, and we want 6 combinations, we duplicate 20 3 times. So we now have:
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)]

Next, we do 13 – 0. Look at the underlying.
13 – 0 = (5) + (5+3)

Then 13 * 2. Now you might think why 2 not 3 (because 13 is sum of 2 subarrays), right? Proceed and I will explain it later:

Finally, 20 * 3 - 13 * 2. Visually, this can be understood as follows:
[(<s>**5+3**</s>+1) + (<s>**5+3**</s>+1+2)]
[(<s>**5**</s>+3+1) + (<s>**5**</s>+3+1+2)]
[(5+3+1) + (5+3+1+2)].
Note that while the same cancellation strategy is applied horizontally, each 13 is the group of subarrays used for cancellation vertically. So how many 13 will we use? Depends on how many columns we have, which in turn 1 + number of bigger numbers to its right.

Then you might ask, if we do “racc * ln - lacc * rn”, does that mean “ln” always has to be ≥ “rn”? No, repeat the above for [5,1,3,2], and we can get the following cancellation outcome.
[(<s>**5**</s>+1) + (<s>**5**</s>+1+3) + (<s>**5**</s>+1+3+2)]
[(5+1) + (5+1+3) + (5+1+3+2)]
